body_text.text: Practical Steps to Improve Air Flow in Long-Term Care Resident Rooms to Reduce COVID-19 3
Keywords: COVID, Corona, Skilled Nursing Facilities, airborne infection isolation, respiratory droplets, 6

The potential for spread of COVID-19 infections in Skilled Nursing Facilities and other Long-Term Care 10 sites poses new challenges for Nursing Home Administrators to protect patients and staff. It is anticipated 11 that as Acute Care Hospitals reach capacity, Nursing Homes may retain COVID-19 infected residents 12 longer prior to transferring to an Acute Care Hospital. This article outlines 5 pragmatic steps that Long-13

Term Care facilities can take to manage airflow within resident rooms to reduce the potential for spread 14 of infectious airborne droplets into surrounding areas including hallways and adjacent rooms, using 15 strategies adapted from negative pressure isolation rooms in acute care facilities. Step #1 -Estimate Total Room Volume, Ventilation, and Differential Pressure -As an example, in a 15' 61 by 20' room with 8' ceilings, the total room volume is 2,400 cubic feet. Assuming the ASHRAE 170 62 guideline of 2 ACH, the room is receiving approximately 80 cubic feet per minute (cfm) of outdoor air 63 from the rooftop air handler along with some recirculated air. Estimate room pressure at the hallway door 64 using a manometer, tissue or plastic to determine air current direction. contact the Industrial Hygienist to design appropriate safe retrofit options. Anticipate higher energy costs 78 and increased noise as conditioned make-up air is drawn from hallways into rooms and discharged 79 outdoors.

Step #3 -Increase Efficiency of Filtration -AII rooms are typically equipped with MERV 7 prefilters and 82 MERV 14 final filters which remove up to 98% of airborne particles as small as 0.3 to 1.0 microns in 83 diameter (typical diameter of respiratory droplets). Place lower efficiency filters on HVAC return 84 registers to reduce airborne droplets entering the return air stream. Discuss these options for increasing 85 filter efficiency with your HVAC contractor to ensure compatibility with your HVAC system. 86

FIGREF0.text: Introduction -Pathways for COVID-19 Spread in Long-Term Care 18With the Pandemic spread of COVID-19 infections, and understanding that the virus is spread via19    droplet nuclei, as well as fomite transmission from surfaces,1 patients and staff in Skilled Nursing20 Facilities, Assisted Living, or other Long Term Care facilities face special challenges, as elderly 21 populations with pre-existing conditions are at higher infection risk. 2 22 According to the California Department of Public Health, 3 "Most SNFs do not have airborne infection 23 isolation rooms (AIIR) for placement of residents with COVID-19 infection… Place residents with 24 suspected or confirmed COVID-19 infection in single occupancy rooms (or cohorted in multi-occupancy 25 rooms with other residents with confirmed COVID-19 infection) with the door closed. Symptomatic 26 residents and exposed roommates must limit movement outside their room; if they need to leave the 27 room, they should wear a facemask." Atkinson et al, 2009 reported that respiratory droplets from humans (which may include bacteria, fungi 30 and viruses) typically range from 0.5 to 12 microns in diameter, and droplet nuclei < 5 µm can remain 31 airborne for significant periods of time. 4 Doremalen, Bushmaker et al recently reported that COVID-19 32 remains stable in airborne aerosols for at least 3-hours, and can persist on inanimate surfaces for 48-72 33 hours 5 . Kampf, et al reported Corona viruses can live on surfaces up to 9 days. 6 34 35 Based upon the above, it can be seen that techniques for prevention of infection including social 36 distancing, interception of droplet discharge during coughs and sneezes, regular cleaning and disinfection 37 of surfaces, hand-hygiene and the use of Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) are all essential to 38 controlling spread. However, those steps alone are unlikely to provide adequate protection for residents 39 and care providers in Long-Term Care facilities as several Long-Term care facilities have reported 40 COVID-19 outbreaks. 41 42Control of Airflow Essential to Reducing Infection Spread 43In Acute Care Facilities Airborne Infection Isolation (AII) rooms are designed to be under a slight 44 negative pressure with respect to adjacent rooms and hallways. This reduces the potential for airborne 45 respiratory droplets from being carried on air currents from the patient into the hallways where it can then 46 be further transported into surrounding areas. General design parameters typically include an exhaust fan 47 discharging above the rooftop drawing air from the AII room at a rate sufficient to place the room under 48 approximately -0.03" water column vacuum relative to the hallway. According to the American Society 49 of Heating Refrigeration and Air-Conditioning Engineers (ASHRAE-170), AII rooms provide 12 air 50 changes per hour with 2 air changes per hour (ACH) from outdoor air.7  ASHRAE 170 recommends that 51 Resident Rooms within Skilled Nursing Facilities provide only 2 ACH outdoor with no pressure 52 differential. 53 5 Steps to Modify Patient Rooms to Negative Pressure 55 Administrators or Facility Managers for Long-Term Care Facilities should consider the following to 56 reduce risk of community infection within the facility. Inform your State Department of Health 57 representative to ensure that these do not result in non-compliance with Life Safety Code or State 58 regulations. 59 60

FIGREF1.text: -Install Supplemental Exhaust Ventilation through Dedicated Exhaust Portals -Inspect the room 67 for sources of dedicated exhaust ports leading to the outside. This may include bathroom or kitchenette 68 exhaust fans or possibly Portable Terminal Air Conditioning (PTAC) Units, but does not include return 69 registers associated with the general HVAC system. Contact an Industrial Hygienist and HVAC 70 contractor to discuss options for supplemental exhaust ventilation through these portals. This may 71 include an in-line fan to increase exhaust discharge from bathroom vents, or increasing the size of exhaust 72 fans. In a 2400 ft 3 resident room, the addition of additional 100 cfm of exhaust discharging from the 73 room to the outdoors would increase air changes per hour (ACH) from 2 to approximately 4.5. A 250 74 cfm booster fan would increase the air exchange rate by approximately 6.5 ACH beyond the 2 ACH 75 already provided by the rooftop air handler. This would remove airborne respiratory droplets 76 approximately 3 times faster than the standard resident room. If there are no apparent exhaust portals, 77
